newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Man jailed for spying on Moroccans in Sweden.
newsitem.headline: Man jailed for spying on Moroccans in Sweden.

text.p: A 52-year-old naturalised Swede, originally from Morocco, was jailed for eight months on Monday for spying on Moroccans in Sweden who opposed the Rabat government.

The man, who held a position of trust in a Moroccan organisation in Sweden for many years, was found guilty of sending information back to Morocco about the activities of Polisario supporters to the authorities in Rabat.
Polisario is an organisation campaigning for autonomy for the Western Sahara.
A court in Gothenburg on Sweden's west coast, heard that the man was charged after Swedish security police tapped the man's phone and kept him under surveillance for several years.
The defendent, who cannot be named under Swedish law, has lived in Sweden for 30 years.
He occasionally sent information through diplomatic channels using the Moroccan embassy in Sweden, the court was told during the month-long trial.
The court was also shown Swedish television news reports and newspaper articles about the political situation in Morocco to prove that supporting Polisario was a punishable offence there.
The defendent admitted forwarding Swedish media reports about Morocco to Rabat but said this did not amount to the charge he faced of illegal information gathering.
